turn.text: Say, if he has not collected the tax, he has a special statutory basis to urge that you may not now change the rules on me.
I didn't collect the tax relying on your ruling.You can't now change that and say you should have collected the tax.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's 6416, is it?

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: That's the Revenue Act of 1926 which is at page 44 of Government's brief.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Is it --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What is 6416?

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: That is a general provision relating to conditions for suits for refund of excise taxes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: In which he -- suppose Justice Black's condition is satisfied, this is a test suit for the 50,000, can he now show no matter what this Court decides, suppose the Court decides against him on this issue, does the stipulation or anything else barring him to -- for making a complain that as to the 50,000 or any part thereof, he in fact did not pass the tax onto the customers?

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: Yes.

He has -- the only issue which has ever been in this case from the outset, the only issue presented by the claim for refund here by the complaint, by the stipulation of fact by the District Judge's findings has been one issue and one only and that is whether or not the rulings exempt the taxpayers' units from the tax, and if they do, are they valid?
Are they consistent with the statute?
That is the only issue the taxpayer in his claim for refund limits himself to that single ground and makes no other contention of the nature that has been discussed here.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Heffron, let me ask you once more.
I said, I am -- to straighten my mind.
Has this manufacturer collected from the people he sold these 50,000 machines to the tax that we're discussing here in this case?

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: No.
The taxpayers' counsel in response to an answer stated he had collected the tax with respect to the two units in issue here.
He has stipulated that these two units are test units to determine the applicability of the statute to all of his other units.
He has, at no time, raised the contention that --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I don't care whether he has raised a contention or not, but are we not entitled to know when we're dealing with this case whether he has actually passed that on to -- to the people who bought those things and whether he would get a windfall if he won in this case or -- or whether he would suffer the loss of a million dollars by having to pay the -- the Government a million dollars that -- that he didn't think he had to pay relying on the Government's regulation.
Now, there's a great difference between the two and can't -- can't we find out, can't we know whether he -- he did pass it on to those -- those purchasers in the 50,000?

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: Well, we have assumed that he did not and we do that because --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That he did not what?

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: That he in fact -- I beg your pardon, that he has in fact collected it --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: -- from the customers.
We assume --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You assume that he has.

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: We assume that because this is a matter for the plaintiff to allege in support of his refund suit.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- by his refund --

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: He has never done that.
He has barred on to all the rules with respect to tax refund suits for making that claim at any time now.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Public utility company very often collects rates but that doesn't -- there's no defense to its reduction because it has already collected and windfalls are -- and reimbursement to the consumers is a part of the whole process.

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: Well, we --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I thought the law --

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: -- we are not --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Am I wrong?
So help me.
I thought the law required that he collected that excise tax to collect it from the customer.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, require.

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: Well, that is -- it does not require him.
In fact, it is passed on to the vendee.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: In that way?

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: Yes, that is why the statute requires as a condition to bringing a suit for refund that you either assert that you did not collect it from the vendee or procure the vendees' consent to bringing the action.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is it your position or is the Government to take this position, it is for making the people pay back money to the Government, pay money to the Government where under the circumstances which he's indicated here?
Suppose -- suppose he has collected -- suppose he sold this and collected the tax from the consumer, you say then that the Government has a right to get it back, is that it?

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: As oppose he has sold them without collecting it from the consumer on the basis that the statute didn't require him to collect, what's the Government's position there?

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: If that in fact were sold, and we don't believe it's sold, if it were so, he could have asserted under the --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But I'm not talking about what he could've done --

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- can he do it now?

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: No, he cannot do it now.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You mean on these two?

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: He cannot do it on any.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: This is a test case.
It governs all these units.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Why is this not raised in your answer then if this is your defense?
I don't find them.

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: Well, because this would be -- this is a ground for the taxpayer to have urged in support of his refund suit.
This would have been the way he could have had this case decided without embarking upon a controversy over rulings or administrative practice.
He simply had to make this factual assertion, which is within his knowledge, “We did not collect the tax from our vendees.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You didn't raise this in the -- below or in the District Court as near as I can with the record.

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: This would be a ground which the -- under our view, the plaintiff must assert in his claim for refund.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: You never said that below.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: But if you tried the case on agreed issues below how on the world that he have an opportunity to raise any such thing?

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: He had all the opportunity to raise it in the claim for refund.
This is the -- this is the basic document which a taxpayer files in -- in stating to the Commissioner why he is entitled to his money back, why the tax was illegally imposed.
He can state 10 reasons.He can state one reason.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: This is the first time this point emerges.
I -- I don't understand why if this is a defense, it wasn't brought out below or tendered or offered or argued.

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: Well, we suggest that simply to indicate that there is no question of retroactivity in this case because the taxpayer has not lay the essential factual foundations upon which he could base it, but this is not.
This is a matter which would be set forth in the claim for a refund.
That's one of the reasons why he is entitled to a refund.
He could have two grounds.
One ground is, as we construe the ruling, we are exempt from the tax and that ruling, as so construed, is valid.
Now --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Is there any way we can have you fellows start this thing all over again?

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I've never seen this, by this confusing case that's up in here.

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And I'd like to put another thing to you.

It may not -- a manufacturer may, on the guides of passing on a tax, put an extra imposition upon his customers and he may have -- the manufacturer may have done that in this case and still claim that he is not subject to this tax even though he could have told his customer and he was so that there are two questions in this case.
One, is he subject to a tax?
Never mind what he's relation with his customers are.

Two, if in fact he exacted -- if in fact he relied on a tax which he now challenges, even though he relied, that even though the Government rightly now taxes him on the representations made, the Chief Justice has questioned this Court, he relied improperly on his duty to not to pass on a tax which you're now charging with --

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: No --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- so that the fact that he passed it on, doesn't settle all the questions in this case, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: No, it does not and I don't -- we haven't asserted that it does.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Certainly go within the -- the power, the taxability under the statute.

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: We say there is no question of whether he collected the tax in this case.
It is not in the case because it is not part of his cause of action.
He hasn't relied upon any such contention.
This would be a reason why the exaction of the tax is unlawful.
He is bound by the allegations in his claim for refund and in the complaint.
He has never made the smallest suggestion of such a question.
As a matter of fact, he repudiated it at the trial.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It is relevant --

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: He said, "Whether we collected the tax is not in this case at all."
The only question we raised is the ruling.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It is relevant to the claim that the Government and the Commissioner is now going back on his regulation.
He says his regulation walks out on him for some such phrase as Justice Harlan used that -- that you yourself said.
The Commissioner is now scuttling regulations.

If his regulations failed him or properly or in -- in a business way lead a manufacturer to pay us -- to pass on that tax to the customer, it would be unfair now to make him out of -- put him out of profit, is that right?

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And therefore, there are two very distinct questions.

One, whether in fact there was a reliance on what now turns out to be an invalid or an enforceable regulation and then he must come within the statutes which showed that he did rely on, would be out of pocket.
And two, a totally unrelated question, what is the taxability of this kind of things?

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: And it is our position that the only issue properly before this Court is to and only that because if the Court will examine the claim for refund, the complaint, the pleadings, the way this case was tried, there was only one issue ever asserted by the taxpayer as a reason why he ought to recover and that is the ruling exempts my units.
He never said, "And alternatively.
If you find it, it does not exempt my units.
I urge because of my reliance that I'd be granted the refund."
He never made that alternative assumption that he is barred by -- by all the rules relating the tax refund suits for making it.
It is not in the claim for refund.
Now, he -- he drafted his claim for refund.
It was open to him to assert any number of grounds why he should recover.
He has never made that assertion.
He has not even making it in this Court.
He is not asserting now that he in fact collected the tax in -- under the provisions of the -- of the estoppel section in the Revenue Act of 1926.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Taking -- taking your premises what you just said and assuming that you were held that the regulation was valid, would the position of this case be send it back to the Court of Appeals to try out the issue as to whether a nominal or actual horsepower was a testing to the regulation?

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: I'm -- I'm sorry I -- I didn't understand the --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: If --

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: -- first part.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: -- the regulation is a valid regulation despite the Government's present position, then would not the proper disposition be to send this case back for determination as to the dispute between, namely, whether it's actual horsepower or nominal horsepower that the regulation refers to.

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: No, we -- we would say no because I can't conceive of the finding that the ruling is proper without also determining whether or not the horsepower is determined in terms of actual horsepower or nominal horsepower if --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well, we can't determine that.

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: Well, that --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: That's for the lower court to determine that issue.
It was never determined by the Court of Appeals because they said horsepower was an irrelevancy and that the regulation was invalid.

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: Well, we are here to sustain the view of the Court of Appeals.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well, I understand that.

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: I mean that is an alternative position here.

One position is that the ruling, if construed in terms of nominal horsepower, imposes the tax and even though that test may too narrowly restrict the statute, that -- that would not be an issue here because it does apply to these units.
On the other hand, if it is an actual horsepower test, it is clearly invalid because these units which are taxable by every conceivable criterion would be exempt from the tax.
So we say there is no basis upon which to remand it to the District Court here.
These units are taxable under the statute by any test that can be conceived of.
The horsepower test is not rationally consistent with the statute.
Therefore, the Court of Appeals was correct in reversing the District Court in holding that the units were taxable.
That's our basic position.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Heffron, in the trial court, you stipulated that the -- or the Government stipulated that these units were of the household type.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now, may I ask you this question?
If it had not been for that stipulation, would there been -- have been any issues open to counsel or to the taxpayer that are not open to him in the case with the stipulation?

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: No, precisely the same issues would be involved.
The taxpayer would still be contending that under the ruling, however -- whatever the statute says, under the ruling, and this is his sole contention, "Your ruling exempts my units from tax."
Now, there's nothing in the ruling which refers in terms to household type.
There is nothing in the statute.
It has always been open for -- to the taxpayer to say, "My unit is not self-contained for reasons A, B and C.
All of my unit is not household type for reasons D, E and F."
He has never said that.
He has said only one thing and one thing only at every stage and that is “Because of the horsepower test in your rulings, my units are exempted."
Now, if this -- if this Court should hold the statute, it only applies to self-contained units, there would be no further issues to litigate here.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, let me ask you this now.
Excuse me.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Go -- go finish.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I understand his contention that you are estop and I understand your contention that in someway we are estop by you having agreed that this 50,000 would be the same as the two.
Now -- however, there's a provision with reference to appeal that we construed in (Inaudible) which called attention to the fact that the statute says that we dispose of the case as justice requires.

Now, let us assume that we hold the statute is -- is valid under your claim, not under his, that would mean, of course, that he did pass on the tax in the two and he would not be entitled to have that retried anymore to but why do we have to say that with the situation changing as it has, they shouldn't have a chance to have the case reopened for that to be tried out in the court below if -- whether he passed it on or not, except by -- should you stipulate it so that if justice required it, we shouldn't do that?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: In your stipulation -- does your stipulation -- is your stipulation a stipulation that bars them from saying as to the none two cases, the other 50,000, they didn't pass it on?
I don't think your stipulation does that.
It merely says that this is a stipulation as to the scope and the efficacy of the -- of the ruling of the Commission, is that right?

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: Yes.
Well, the taxpayer can no longer file a claim -- no, I beg your pardon.

I'm going to say, if the stipulation means anything here, the only reason the Commissioner refrained from collecting the tax on these units was because of a stipulation that this was a test case and the disposition of the tax with respect to these --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: On the merits --

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: -- two units would control the others.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- of the legality of the tax.
On the merits of the legality of the tax not to be passed it on and therefore, he's not out of pocket.

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: I said with regard to the rights of the plaintiffs to obtain a refund here and they would be limited again by the pleading -- by the claim for refund which is the basic document which they drafted to shape the issues in this litigation.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: In this case, but would they as to the 50,000?

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: Yes, we say they would.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Why should the Government want a holding for these 50,000 units on this so-called ambiguous stipulation?
If you conceive that under the law, he may have a right to get refund because he has not passed them on, why should the Government take that position?

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: Well, we don't conceive that under the -- under any view of the law, they have a right to refund here.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I -- I understand that.
Well, I understand you do conceive that in a test over this that if he has not passed this tax on, he would have a right to show that under the section to which you referred in order to get a refund.

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: I say -- we -- we say he had a right to show that and did not avail himself of that opportunity.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That he had a right -- had a right below but you want to hold him on the 50,000 on the basis of the two.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Are you saying, Mr. Heffron, we could not authorize him to amend that claim of refund if that's so important in order to set up the facts which would bring him within the right to a statutory relief?

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: No.
I'm not -- I'm not suggesting that.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: He could do that, couldn't he, as to the 50,000 units?

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: I suppose this Court could direct me.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: But we do say that as this litigation was tried, the taxpayer never raised that claim.
He never raised it.
That would be tantamount to a taxpayer suing and saying, "The reason why I'm entitled to refund is because the transaction is not taxable for X.”

Having gone up to this Court and losing, he is given an opportunity to go back to the District Court and say, "Well, I have another reason which I never mentioned before as to why these units are not taxable."

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What problem is that if that's -- if he's entitled to something under the law that Congress has passed?

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: Well, we say that it is so clear that these units are --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, I doubt this test, [Laughs] you would take it the law is clear and so forth.[Laughter]

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: Well -- well --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But the -- also, the law is clear, isn't it, I understood you from that statute as a man who pays the tax, an excise tax and he's relied on a ruling of the remedy which turns out to be bad, the Congress is seen fit to give him a special relief under the section to which you refer us.
Now, if that's true in this case, why should the Government insist that he'd be cutoff from that because of that test?

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: Well, because that -- that issue came into this case simply by way of the Government's attempting to show this Court that there was no collection of the tax on the theory that if there was such -- that if the taxpayer has failed to collect it, they would have asserted it and won their case based on this estoppel ground.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But isn't the --

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: But they never asked for the benefit of this statute.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But isn't a fact that they were -- isn't a fact that the bone of contention in this controversy was the taxability of these units, is that right?
That's what the litigation was about.

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: The -- the right --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: If this litigation was the Government's claim to have a right to tax and their claim that, as a matter of statutory construction and regulation, you did not have a right to tax.

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: There --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Wasn't that the issue?

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And therefore, the question, his collateral question, each side was so -- he was as -- he was as confident on his reading of the law as you are of yours and the question whether he's entitled to get a refund because he would be out of pocket wasn't in -- perhaps in the conscious contemplation of the parties.

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: Well, we -- we say that it -- that it was.
But in any event, we say that a position which would grant him --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: How do you know it was?
You're saying it was because he didn't raise that as a claim.

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: Well, this was raised below.
In the District Court, he had an opportunity.
The Government counsel, in his closing remarks to the District Judge, said, "Why hasn't he alleged that he failed to collect the tax?
We've conceded that this ruling is ambiguous.
Why hasn't he alleged it to you, District Judge?
Why doesn't he make that claim now?"
And the response was, and this is in the record and the Court can read it there, the response was, "There is nothing in the record about what we did about this tax and that's not in the case."
And that is why the taxpayer --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's exactly why he wanted to get a ruling for the future.

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: Because --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: They didn't merely wanted to be put hold for a stuff that -- money they spent, they wanted to get a ruling for the future.

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: As a matter of fact, the Court will see from the record that this taxpayer stated below, "There is no issue of the estoppel.
We will not prevent you from arguing that your ruling -- that the ruling, if construed, to exempt us from tax is invalid."
He stated that below.
He has never sought the benefit of this provision.
As a matter of fact, he repudiated the suggestion that he produced evidence to show that he, in fact, failed to collect the tax from his vendees.
The closing remarks --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) full time --

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: This --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- without either of you arguing the real merit of the case that is before us, namely, what's the scope of the statute.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Very well.
Mr. Rothschild, I'm -- I want to ask you a question.
I don't want you to reargue your case.

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: I won't, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You took your time, but I want to ask you the case because I want to know before we adjourn.
And I'm speaking now to these 50,000 units.

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Did you pass a tax on to your -- to your purchasers and collected on the theory that you are going to pay it to the Government and now seek to -- to deprive the Government of the right to collect that tax and to keep that money or did you, relying upon the regulations and rulings of the Department, failed to pass that on to your -- to your purchasers in which event you would now owe the Government a million dollars or so out of your own pocket?
Which of the two is correct?

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: The latter, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: The latter is true?

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: Yes.
Now, I know -- I know you don't want to reargue.
May I ask --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: -- may I state just one thing?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, yes, you may answer that question rather boldly.

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: That's right.
In connection with that question on why it is not in the record, is that proper?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, but that is your answer that you would now be stuck for a million or so dollars --

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- that you have not passed on to your customers.

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: And that is the -- that is the point.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And as -- as to this two -- the two -- the inferences in the litigation, what is that fact there that you (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: On these two units?
We certainly did as I explained to, I think was Justice Whittaker.

These were units that happened to have been sold to -- directly to a lawyer and to an accountant of the taxpayer before it came to our attention that -- that these units were exempt under the rulings because they had been mislabeled.
We simply selected these two units which had a $29.93 was paid to the Government without a protest passed on to the consumer and collected from him on these units.

And it was after we decided to bring a test suit that we happened to pick these two units, and it was after that point that we sold the $50,000 units, and we brought these suits on these two test units simply to test the taxability of the 50,000.

And there is no conceivable procedural way in which we could've put on any evidence such as Mr. Heffron says, "We should have put on to prove that we had suffered a loss in the 50,000 without going through 50,000 claims for refund in -- in the same manner."

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Tell me this.

Is it -- is it strange that I should think that it is strange that you should stipulate that 50 -- as to 50,000 cases, they should be governed by these two instances as a test suit when there's such a cardinal difference between the two?

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: No, because the only -- the only similarity, Your Honor, and the only reason that -- that we stipulate it was because these suits in these air conditioners, the 50,000 in physical content, in size, in horsepower were the same as the two and --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But -- but there was all the difference in the world and in the one case, you wouldn't be out of pocket and in the other cases, you would be.

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: Well, we'd be out of pocket.
In a sense, we pay back $29.93 but that --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, I know but -- but --

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: But --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- if a case is a test case, then presumably it has the same ingredients as those for which it is a test case.

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: Well, it's a test case for one purpose, Your Honor.
It was a test case to determine the applicability of the excise tax to units of the size described in the stipulation of facts.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But suppose you were wrong in your law, you could still recover for the 50,000.

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: If we're wrong in our law, Your Honor, and we are -- and here's -- here's what will happen.

If we're wrong and the Government wins this case, then we will have to pay by over a million dollars of taxes, file claims for refund, hope that we can persuade the Treasury, which I don't think we will, that we should -- that they shouldn't charge us this tax, then we would have to file tests -- additional suits and make affirmative proof that we -- that we absorbed the tax on all of these 50,000 units.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But you just said to the Chief Justice that you haven't -- that you didn't (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: Well, I've got to prove that in 50,000 cases.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All I'm saying is if it does strike (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: I mean it's not in the record.
Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It just strikes me.
It's a little odd that you didn't need yourself an act of the (Inaudible) so important to the matter.

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: Well, that's the only act that we have, Your Honor.
We -- we made a test suit to determine the applicability of the tax.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- based out a very important basis on which you could recover a million dollars.

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: No, we couldn't possible recover it on that basis --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now, Mr. --

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: -- on this procedure.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- Rothschild, may I ask you one -- just one more --

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- more question?
You complained of the shift in the Government's position on the stipulation that they made concerning the household type of --

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: That is right.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- of these units.
Will you answer me this question if you can, please?

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: If that -- if that stipulation had been -- not been made by the Government --

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- would there have been any issues available to you in this lawsuit that were -- that were actually foreclosed by reason of this stipulation?

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: Well, certainly, Your Honor.

Household type, whether or not these air conditioners were primarily designed for -- to meet the needs of a household was a question of fact which was not tried because of the Government's stipulation.
The other question is whether they are self-contained which is the new issue raised by the Government on its brief on the merits.
Self-contained is now a word of art because the Government has actually an exhibit saying that it covers anything from a small portable to 1000 horsepower plant.

And the only expression of the industry as to the meaning of self-contained, and that's urged by the Government's issues of fact, the only expression of the industry takes in horsepower and the Government itself says horsepower applies so that if self-contained -- so that if these units are just self-contained as a matter of law as the Government contains now, why would they be relying as they do in their brief, Your Honor, on the horsepower test on the understanding of the industry and on the intention of the Commissioner?
Those are issues of fact which were not raised in the trial court which are raised in this Court and which we have had no opportunity to meet.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: That's true on both.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Let me ask you one question --

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- about that issue of fact.
I thought it was conceded that these whole household room units.

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: They are room units.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, why -- why do you say there'd be a question as whether or not they were household appliance?

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: Because the larger -- and this -- the evidence shows this, Your Honor, in the record.
The larger units are considered commercial units.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: There is an arbitrary line --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I'm not talking about the horsepower question.
I'm just talking about whether they were households.

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: Well, that's -- that's the principal distinction between household and commercial is size.
That's been carried --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you mean when it get above -- you -- when it get above one ton, they are not household?

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: When you get up to one or one and a half, you will find their primary use is -- is not in house -- and that was certainly true when the regulation was passed in 1948, the -- there's consumption.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Now, I want to ask you one other question.

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Curiosity maybe.

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Doesn't that tax go up on June the 1st?

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: No, Your Honor, unless I'm wrong.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: On the household units?
It's been advertised that it's going up on June the1st in all the places.
And they told me it was going up June the 1st, it'd be by now.[Laughter]
Do you say it's not going up?
Did -- did Congress not increase it right -- recently?

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: Oh, no, I think it's still 10%.
I would refer to the Government.
I don't know.
Is there any evidence?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That means this case is done.

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: That reference is probably to the applicability of the new regulations.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Oh, the new regulations.
That's what --

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- is being talked about.

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: All would impose the tax on units which had (Inaudible) not been taxable under the rulings.

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: Well, yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: On June the 1st.

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: Well, that -- that must be --

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: Oh, that is in effect already but it only applies to units which were sold by the manufacturer subsequent to a given date.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Subsequent to the time this --

turn.speaker: howard_a_heffron
turn.label: Mr. Howard A. Heffron
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: This new regulation --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- ruling (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: -- that came out.
And the new regulation, by the way, also creates an administrative definition of self-contained as Your Honors will know.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. --

turn.speaker: edwin_a_rothschild
turn.label: Mr. Edwin A. Rothschild
turn.text: Thank you.
Thank you gentlemen.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- Mr. Rothschild.[Laughter]
